bibl.title: Letter from [James E. Peabody] to Jonathan Mayhew Wainwright, November 18, 1929

div1.p: [Peabody] thanks Wainwright for his support of the bill to honor the yellow fever experiment participants. Peabody is delighted that Agramonte was included, and glad that Marie Gorgas was not.

div1.head: Letter from [James E. Peabody] to Jonathan Mayhew Wainwright, November 18, 1929
div1.p:
You must think me the most ungrateful man you ever met, not to have made
any acknowledgement of your wonderful work in getting through Congress the Yel-
low Fever Bill. You will forgive me, I am sure, when I tell you that I was
ill with neurastheia from early in January to the last of October, and that
the writing of even a short letter to my three children seemed impossible.
I am in fine shape once more, and since I have retired from New York School
teaching on full pension of approximately half pay, I have the disposing of
my time, and am enjoying life to the full--busier than ever before, but with
no necessity to rise at 5:30 every morning in order to get to school on time.

I enclose a carbon copy (sorry it is not better, but perhaps you can make
it out if you read the marked paragraphs with a sheet of white paper beneath.)
Cor Biology Committee plan to send this out to all members of the New York As-
sociation of Biology Teachers, to all who contributed to the Kissinger Fund,
and to the long list of those who have helped us in the cause. As you will
see (ps. 3 and 4) I plan to give my lecture in two parts: the first will be
an account of the experiments in Cuba that led to The Conquest of Yellow Fever;
the second, and by no means less interesting account of the later history of
those heroes, and the story of the collection of the Kissinger fund and of
the triumph of the Wainwright-Copeland Bill in Congress. I know of no more
important lesson for history and civics classes, as well as for biology student.

Before I mimeograph this letter (see enclosed carbon copy), which will of
course be very much briefer, I must know if you are willing to complete your
splendid work by introducing a bill to give the four members of the Reed Board
the $250 that was approved by the Committee on Military Affairs after the
hearing on April 11, 1928. Can you tell me whether any objection was raised
before the Committee voted to recommend the bill? I am sure you would have
the enthusiastic support of Dr. Fosdick's Citizen Committee, and the active
help of hundreds of those who know this story. I hope to use my lantern slides
during the next six months wherever I can get an audience and enough to pay
my expenses, Surgeon General Ireland and Surgeon General Cumming would do all
they can to help you, for the compromise bill you had to agree to violates all
the principles that ought to obtain in granting higher pensions to army offi-
cers.

You do not know how delighted everybody is that Dr. Agramonte's name was
included in all three of the lists. How did you do it? All the doctors and
government leaders with whom I talked said that the inclusion of his name would
wreck the legislation, much as it deserved to pass, if a doctor outside the
country was named. In the amended bill, recommended by the late and lamented
Mr. Frothingham's sub-Committee, is the name of Mrs. William Crawford Gorgas.
We regretted the inclusion of any name not directly concerned in those memorable
experiments of the Reed Board in 1900, and were glad this name did not appear
in the final draft of the legislation, passed on February 28, 1929. Can you
give me the history of this “in” and “out” of the Gorgas name, or is it a secret
of the Committee Room?

I find it is possible to give my lecture (using half my lantern slides)
in about 30 minutes. This I have done when talking before Rotary and Lions
Glabs and in churches and schools. But it has meant a breathless desk over
the main points of the story. If I am to have only a short time at my dis-
posal I choose to tell either the record of that marvelous six months of
1900 down in Cuba, or to give an account of the experiences we have had in
raising $8000 for Kissinger and in backing you and Senator Copeland in get-
ting this long delayed justice for the Yellow Fever Heroes. You have done
far more than that; you have opened a door for the grateful recognition of
the heroes of peace. Is a further result of your work those past years Mrs.
Goldberger, whose husband gave his life in researches on spotted fever, now
receives $125 a month.

I come now to another way in which I bespeak your help. Opportunities
to give my yellow fever lectures (and others as well) in this part of New
England where I used to study and teach at Harvard, are coming in at a sur-
prising rate. Supt. Snow of the Boston Schools says he will be only too
glad to have me speak in any of the Boston schools. Newton and Wellesley
also wish the talks. I have engagements in churches and in rotary and Kiwanis
Clubs. Some of the colleges wish the talks. I have a complete set of slides
on the Cuban story, one that probably could not be duplicated without the
use of my negatives. The second story, however, that of getting needed leg-
islation, is one that appeals to me, though in a different way, about as
strongly as the first. As I have already said in other letters my faith in
democracy and in our public servants (in spite of the present Senate fiasco)
has been immeasurably increased. Apparently anyone with a worthy cause and
a determination to succeed can get a bill through Congress if he can find a
Wainwright who will do the set for him.

The paragraph above is a long introduction to what I am driving at. In
order to make that second story vivid I must have an autographed picture of
Congressman Wainwright, a good picture of the House Office building, of your
office, of the room in which the Committee on Military Affairs met, a picture
of said Committee, and a number of others. I need to scoure, if possible,
hundreds of copies of the original and the variously amended forms of the
Wainwright-Copeland bill, and on the final form in which it was passed and
signed,--a copy of each of these to be left as a sort of exhibit an schools
where I lecture. I am sure students in history and civics would be immensely
interested. I may find it possible to write up and have the Museum of Natural
History publish another pamphlet similar to THE CONQUEST OF YELLOW FEVER,
with case such title as WA COLONEL WAINWRIGHT BROUGHT CONGRESS TO ITS CASES.
I plan to have lantern slides made of the vital points of the campaign as
portrayed in some of the precious letters which the Rockefeller Foundation
suggests should be filed for permanent keeping in Johns Hopkins Library of
the History of Medicine. I hope to secure also autographed pictures of the
members of the Fosdick Citizens Committee and of various Washington Officials
who have helped us so much. If you think it is not an imposition on your
busy time, I should like very much to drive our car down to our old home in
White Plains, leave my wife there for visits with friends, while I secure the
pictures and lantern slides I need. I can secure more very valuable material
from those wonderful friends in Baltimore and Washington. I should like to
have my wife there with me at the opening of Congress. Is this all a wild
dream, or are you willing to help me secure the needed material? We do so
hope we can complete to the satisfaction of all that wonderful job so well be-
gan.

I shall appreciate an early reply, so I may know what to do about what
plans to make.
